bestBHT.bht: Jesus instructs us to do good and lend generously, without expecting anything in return. We are called to help even those who seem to be in despair, reflecting the kindness of God towards the unthankful and wicked. Our acts of kindness should surpass worldly standards, demonstrating pure liberality and considering the needs of others. By doing so, we reveal ourselves to be the true children of God, whose character and love extend to all, including our enemies.

Henry Alford: not expecting any payment from them" - Euthymius
causing no one to despair... refusing no one" - Ancient Syriac version
not despairing, i.e. without anxiety about the result" - Commentary author.
Marvin Vincent: Hoping for nothing again [μηδεν απελπιζοντες] . A later Greek word, only here in New Testament, and meaning originally to give up in despair, a sense which is adopted by some high authorities, and by Rev., never despairing.
According to this, the sense here is, 'do good as those who consider nothing as lost.'
Children of the Highest [υιοι υψιστου] . Rev., rightly, sons. Compare Matthew 5:45, Matthew 5:48.
John Calvin: Christ only exhorts us to perform our duties freely, and tells us that mercenary acts are of no account in the sight of God.
He alone is truly beneficent to his neighbors, who is led to assist them without any regard to his own advantage, but looks only to the necessities of each.
When believers lend, they ought to go beyond heathens; or, in other words, they ought to exercise pure liberality.
Archibald T. Robertson: Never despairing... Jesus means that we are not to despair about getting the money back. We are to help the apparently hopeless cases."
By 'never despairing' or 'giving up nothing in despair,' Jesus means that we are not to despair about getting the money back. We are to help the apparently hopeless cases."
God the Father is kind towards the unkind and wicked.
John Gill: But love ye your enemies,.... As before urged in Luke 6:27 and do good and lend; not to your friends only, but to your enemies; hoping for nothing again.

The meaning is, that such who from principles of grace, and with right views do such acts of kindness and beneficence to their fellow creatures and Christians, shall be, made manifest, and declared to be the children of God.
For he is kind to the unthankful and to the evil; by causing his sun to rise, and his rain to fall on them, as on the righteous and the good.

bhtAttempts.bht: Jesus teaches us in this verse to do good and lend to others without expecting any payment or favors in return. We are to help even those who may seem hopeless, without anxiety about the result. Instead, we are called to be like the children of God who show kindness to the unkind and wicked, just as God the Father is kind towards them. In our acts of kindness and generosity, we are to go beyond worldly standards and exercise pure liberality, not seeking our own advantage but considering the needs of others. By doing so, we demonstrate that we are truly the children of God, reflecting His character and love towards all, including our enemies.

Jesus calls us to do good and lend without expecting anything in return. We are to help those who may seem hopeless, displaying the kindness of God towards the unkind and wicked. Our acts of kindness should go beyond worldly standards, showing pure liberality and considering the needs of others. By doing so, we demonstrate that we are truly the children of God, reflecting His character and love towards all, including our enemies.

Jesus teaches us to do good and lend without expecting any payment in return. We are to help even those who seem hopeless, without anxiety about the outcome. By showing kindness to the unkind and wicked, we reflect the character of God, who is kind to all. Our acts of kindness should go beyond worldly standards, demonstrating pure liberality and considering the needs of others. Through these actions, we reveal ourselves to be the true children of God.

Jesus instructs us to do good and lend generously, without expecting anything in return. We are called to help even those who seem to be in despair, reflecting the kindness of God towards the unthankful and wicked. Our acts of kindness should surpass worldly standards, demonstrating pure liberality and considering the needs of others. By doing so, we reveal ourselves to be the true children of God, whose character and love extend to all, including our enemies.

Jesus calls us to do good and lend without expecting any payment in return. We are to help even the seemingly hopeless cases, without despairing or anxiously seeking the outcome. By displaying kindness toward the unkind and wicked, we reflect the character of God, who is kind to all. Our acts of kindness should not be driven by personal gain, but rather by a genuine concern for others. Through these selfless actions, we demonstrate that we are the true children of God, reflecting His love toward all, including our enemies.
